column1: ARTEM-IS (Agreed Reporting Template for EEG Methodology - International Standard) template for ERP

column3: question
column4: options
column5: instructions

column3: At the time of document creation, what is the current ARTEM-IS template for?
column4:
- Documenting a planned pipeline
- Documenting a pipeline that has been applied to study data

column3: Current title of the study/pipeline
Is the current title the same as it appears in related publications?
column4:
- no
- yes
- final decision not made yet

column3: Has the current study or pipeline been known by a different name or a working title previously?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Working title
Authors of the study in the following format: family-name, other names. Each author separated by a semicolon and a space.
Has the study resulted in any published articles, conference presentations or research reports at this stage?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Do any of these publications have a DOI?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: DOIs of related publications, separated by a semicolon and a space.
Are there any web-accessible publications that do not have a DOI?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Provide links to non-DOI publications, separated by a semicolon and a space.
Has this study resulted in any datasets archived in a persistent, version controlled repository, administered independently from the authorship team?
column4:
- yes
- no
column5: For example, a Github repository

column3: What types of data are available?
column4:
- raw EEG data
- individual epochs
- averaged ERPs for individual participants
- grand average ERPs for all conditions, amplitude measures
- component amplitudes/latencies and other measures for statistical analysis
- other

column3: Types of data not included in list
Do any of these datasets have a DOI?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Dataset DOIs separated by a semicolon and a space.
Are there any datasets that do not have a DOI?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Provide links to non-DOI datasets, separated by a semicolon and a space.
Has this study resulted in any supplementary materials other than data and publications?
column4:
- yes
- no
column5: For example, visualization plots, tables, lists of stimuly, etc.

column3: Which supplementary materials are available publically?
column4:
- list of stimulus descriptions (e.g. list of objects shown in images)
- stimuli
- codes or files with the experimental task
- other

column3: Which other supplementary materials are available?
Provide the link to the location of supplementary materials on the web.
Are any elements in the study currently covered by a license allowing for reuse?
column4:
- code
- data
- other elements
column5: For example, code used to run the study, data arising from the study

column3: License type for code.
column4:
- Public Domain
- Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and License
- Creative Commons Zero 1.0 Universal
- Multiple
- Other
column5: More info on licence types: https://bids-specification.readthedocs.io/en/stable/99-appendices/02-licenses.html

column3: Licence types for each code element, with name of element followed by license type, separated by semicolon and a space
License type for code (other than listed)
License type for data.
column4:
- Public Domain
- Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and License
- Creative Commons Zero 1.0 Universal
- Multiple
- Other
column5: More info on licence types: https://bids-specification.readthedocs.io/en/stable/99-appendices/02-licenses.html

column3: Licence types for each data element, with name of element followed by license type, separated by semicolon and a space
License type for data (other than listed)
Name of each licensed study element followed by license type, with listed elements separated by semicolon and a space.
column5: For example, derivatives, figures, slides, etc.

column3: List keywords, separated by semicolons followed by space.
At the time of writing, does the project have financial support from a funding agency?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: If this project is being funded, please list grant numbers and funding agencies, separated by a semicolon and a space.
At the time of writing has the study been approved by an ethics committee?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: If the study has been aproved by an ethics comittee, list the approval ID and institution which granted it. If there are multiple approvals, separate them by semicolons followed by space.
Do you have any acknowledgments to add in addition to authors or funding?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Acknowledgements
Do you have any instructions on how you want this study to be cited or otherwise acknowledged?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Citation instructions
How were the EEG electrodes placed?
column4:
- cap or net
- single electrodes

column3: What kind of cap or net did you use?
column4: - preset:eeg_cap_types

column3: Please specify your cap or net manufacturer
Please indicate the cap or net model.
Manufacturer of the electrodes
Model of electrodes
Did electrodes have pre-amplifiers?
column4:
- no - passive electrodes
- yes - active electrodes

column3: What material were electrodes made of?
column4:
- Ag/Ag-Cl
- tin
- other

column3: Specify the material that the electrodes were made of.
Type of conductive medium used other than listed.
column4:
- conductive gel
- saline solution
- adhesive paste
- none (dry electrodes)
- other

column3: Conductive medium type other than listed.
Make (brand) of the amplifier
column4: - preset:meeg_amplifier_brands

column3: Specify which make (brand) of the amplifiers did you use.
Model of amplifier
Source of triggers
column4:
- photo diode
- auditory trigger/voice key
- combination stim tracker
- presentation software trigger
- other

column3: Source of triggers other than listed.

Describe your trigger signal input. Were your triggers delivered during acquisition (e.g., triggers from photo diode simultaneously recorded while presenting trials) or added after recording (e.g. after analysis of an audio recording of spoken responses)?
column4:
- Online, during acquisition
- Added after recording

column3: Were your triggers delivered to the amplifier or acquisition computer?
column4:
- Amplifier
- Acquisition computer

column3: Were your triggers delivered via an analogue or digital signal format?
column4:
- Analogue (e.g., via a parallel port, serial port, or TCP/IP)
- Digital (including serial port over a USB port (arduino, LabJack U3, or similar))

column3: Do you have other devices (eg. signal boxes, converters, other peripheral devices) to report?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Describe which additional devices you used, and specify their manufacturers and models.
What software did you use for the acquisition?
column4: - preset:meeg_acquisition_softwares

column3: Specify software version if applicable, and software name and version if "other" was selected.
Did you document impedances, or an alternative data aquisition quality measure?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: What is the appropriate acquisition data quality measure for your recording equipment?
column4:
- impedance upper threshold
- impedance range
- a data quality measure alternative to impedances

column3: What was the upper threshold of impedance that you registered in your study?
What was the lowest impedance you registered in this study?
What was the highest impedance you registered in this study?
Report data quality measures provided by your recording system alternative to impedances.
What type of placement/naming convention have you used for the electrode locations?
column4:
- five percent electrode system (extension of the International 10-20 system by Oostenveld & Praamstra (2001))
- commercial geodesic net
- other named system
- custom locations

column3: Specify the electrode placement/naming convention used
column5: Either the name of a standardized placement system (for example, 10-20) or a list of standardized electrode names (for example, [Cz, Pz])

column3: Describe the custom placement of your electrodes relative to anatomical markers or electrode naming/placement systems
column5: E.g. "One electrode, half way between Cz and CP1, was used."

column3: Number of scalp electrodes excluding reference channels, ground channel, VEOG and HEOG.
Did you use an online reference (as opposed to alternative solutions such as Driven Right Leg (DRL))?
column4:
- yes
- no

column3: Where did you place reference electrode(s)?
column4: - preset:eeg_reference_electrodes

column3: What alternative to an online reference (e.g. DRL) did you use? Please describe it.
Online reference location other than listed
Where did you place ground electrode during the recording?
How many EOG channels did you use to record eye movement-dependent voltage?
column4:
- two HEOG channels only
- two VEOG channels only
- two HEOG and two VEOG channels
- no EOG channels
- other

column3: Specify the position of EOG channels you used for the recording
column5: For example, where were they placed? How were they positioned in ajdunct to the rest of the electrodes?

column3: Which of the following online filters have you used?
column4:
- high pass
- low pass
- pass band
- stop band
- notch
- none

column2: online filters high pass cut off
column3: Specify the high-pass filter cut-off used during recording.

column2: online filters high pass cutoff unit
column3: Type of high-pass filter cut-off
column4:
- half-amplitude
- half-power

column2: online filters high pass roll off
column3: Specify the high-pass filter roll off used during recording

column2: online filters low pass cutoff unit
column3: Type of low-pass filter cut-off
column4:
- half-amplitude
- half-power

column2: online filters low pass cut off
column3: Specify the low-pass filter cut-off used during recording.

column2: online filters low pass roll off
column3: Specify the low-pass filter roll off used during recording

column4:
- 50 Hz
- 60 Hz
- other

column3: Describe the stopband frequency of the online notch filter you applied
What was your acquisition sampling rate?
Did you use the same software for all pre-processing steps?
column4:
- yes
- no
column5: Preprocessing steps are fitlering, downsampling, re-referencing, artifact removal, epoching and baseline correction, and other up to the point of data collection

column3: Which software did you use?
column4: - preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

column3: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected, and software name and version if "other" was selected.
Did you use an automated pre-processing pipeline which executes more than artifact removal decisions?
column4:
- yes
- no
column5: For example, this automated pipeline may also include filtering, baseline correction, or re-referencing.

column3: Which automated pre-processing pipeline did you use?
column4:

- HAPPE (Gabard-Durnam et al., 2018)
- HAPPE+ER (Monachino et al., 2021)
- EPOS (Rodrigues et al., 2021)
- other

How many artifact elimination steps did you have?
column5: This section refers to artifact removal (correction, rejection) methods other than elimating participants from the sample, which should be described in the Experimental design and sample section. This section should not include artifact removal within automated pipelines already described above.

column3: What action did you take regarding artifacts in step 1?
column4:
- reject bad trial or bad data segment
- correct by subtraction (blinks, EKG etc.)
- reject channels
- interpolate channels
- multi-step automated approach (e.g., FASTER)

column3: What software did you use for artifact removal in step 1?
column4: - preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

column3: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected and software name and version if "other" was selected.
Did you reject trials or segments of continuous data in step 1?
column4:
- trials
- data segments

column3: How did you define your artifacts in step 1?
column4:
- visual inspection
- pre-set numerical criterion/function
- other

column3: Which artifacts did you remove using visual inspection in step 1?
column4:
- blinks
- saccades
- other occular
- cardiac
- motion and other EMG noise
- alpha waves
- line noise
- other

column3: Which other artifacts did you remove visually?
Describe your numerical criterion/function and provide numerical threshold(s) in step 1.
Describe your method of artifact rejection other than visual inspection or numerical criterion/function. Make sure that there is enough detail for a replication attempt.
Which general method of artifact correction did you use in step 1?
column4:
- regression-based approach (e.g., Gratton et al., 1983, Elbert et al., 1985)
- spatial-filter-based approach (e.g., Dale, 1994)
- ICA-based approaches
- wavelet-based
- wavelet-enhanced ICA (e.g., Khushaba et al, 2013)
- multiple-source-analysis-based approaches (e.g., MSEC by Berg & Scherg, 1994)
- other

column3: Reference to the artifact correction algorithm used in step 1
Describe artifact correction parameters in detail sufficient for replication.
column5: For example, provide numerical parameters, options selected, or describe decision-making process as closely as possible if manual, visual-inspection based decisions were involved.

column5: e.g. for a priori - mean of a window decided in advance; e.g. visual inspection of an a priori decided range or window around a peak found in an a priori decided range; e.g., for data driven - mass uni analysis of the entire epoch, visual inspecion of the entire epoch or a vaguely defined (i.e. flexible) general time range. When you are making this decision, you may want to check out papers by Kriegskorte et al. column5: A priori: the window is selected in advance Data-driven: the measurement window is selected based on data obtained in the current study.
